data.text: Tubeless - Is CushCore Worth the Money?
Is Cush core worth the money? Going tubeless and trying to decide if adding Cush core would be beneficial over just going tubeless.
Personally, I think for mountain biking it makes sense, but for gravel I think it's overkill. If you're worried about riding on a flat, bring a tube.
data.author: Ted Redmer

data.text: I think it depends on the type of gravel. If you're doing a lot of riding in the Flint Hills area of Kansas (ie Unbound), I think it makes a lot of sense. Friend of mine who has done Unbound with and without inserts swears by inserts. But yeah, if you're not riding on really aggressive gravel, it might be overkill. That peace of mind might be worth it regardless.
data.author: Tim Sattler

data.text: If you are worried about pinch flatting a tubeless tire on gravel, I‚Äôd say go to bigger tire vs running cushcore. You are going to add weight either way, with a bigger tire you at least get the extra cushion to go with the weight. 2.0 is the narrowest I‚Äôll run in our area. Sand and fist sized caliche rocks are common. I ride my SS MTB most of the time and it‚Äôs on 29x2.4 and my geared hardtail is on 27.5x2.6. Still ran into some sand that absolutely swallowed up my 2.6s last week.
data.author: Matt Evans

data.text: Man if you have goatheads where you ride, I think they‚Äôre worth it. I‚Äôve literally gone through an entire tire‚Äôs worth of sealant on a single ride and chances are you won‚Äôt be able to find all the spines and will instantly flat if you put a tube in. Also they‚Äôre awesome for peace of mind on bikepacking trips because you can legit ride 20 miles with zero air until you get somewhere you can do proper repairs. That said, my rig is about comfort and going far, NOT about cutting grams so YMMV
data.author: Ken Sears

data.text: yep, goatheads ‚Ä¶ üíÄüíÄüíÄ
data.author: Dirty Freehub

data.text: Totally depends. I‚Äôve used it for Unbound, and was glad to have the insurance and ability to run very low pressures. I don‚Äôt use it in my regular daily setup, but it depends where/what you ride. I was able to comfortably run 6-8 psi lower in my tires due to the support the Cush core provided.
data.author: Peter McKinney

data.text: Yes. You can ride home on your flat.
data.author: Jason Holzworth

data.text: And it provides extra ‚Äúsuspension‚Äù
data.author: Jason Holzworth

data.text: 100%. No questions asked.
data.author: Derek Buckridge

data.text: I'm a towpath and rail-trail goober and it is overkill for me. If I'm riding the nastystuff in a nasty manner on some 650b wheels, I'd look into it.
data.author: Jon Love

data.text: I have them in mine and they are great. I am running 25psi front and rear on carbon rims and love having the cushcore in them on my gravel bike.
data.author: Ben Morgan

data.text: Mountain bike on technical rocky enduro riding, definitely. Gravel bike, not so much. Bit of overkill and adds a lot of rotational weight.
data.author: Ron Williamson

data.text: No. Use the right tire pressure and you‚Äôll be happier.
data.author: Chris Bussiere

data.text: It's a volume space so from my experience it just makes 25psi feel like 30psi
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: Go tubolite instead 27gr

data.author: Lee Duncan

data.text: Depends on your riding imho. Cush adds a huge PITA when changing tires.
data.author: Lee Duncan

data.text: Racing, yes. Not racing, no.
data.author: T.j. Oehmen

data.text: Yes. 100%. Dropped from 30-32psi to 22-24 psi (I‚Äôm 170lbs) and my average speeds went up. Haven‚Äôt had a single flat (knock on wood) since I put them on 1.5 years ago (including unbound this year).
data.author: Adam Bonewitz

data.text: Depends on what and how you ride... if your cornering technique is spotty or you're one of those types who likes to deliberately square off corners to kick up some dirt, or if you like to bomb into sharp rocks, they're 100% worth it... otherwise they're just a placebo that doesn't actually do much on the trail.
data.author: Troy Browning

data.text: If you‚Äôre a heavy rider and you slam rocks it could be a good option. Great for enduro/DH type riding. For most in the gravel/adventure arena I think it‚Äôs an unnecessary weight, expense, and hassle. I start with out and if you have a problem maybe give them a try. So I guess I‚Äôm saying, only run them if you need them‚Ä¶
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: Well, I just landed my 250lbs self on my rear wheel on my hardtail with low tire pressure- on a corner of a cement block‚Ä¶ and my rim doesn‚Äôt look like anything happened to it. No idea how. Might have snake-bit my tire, but the rim is 100% intact and shows no damage. Granted I don‚Äôt do that type of riding on a gravel bike
data.author: Geoff Brown

data.text: Slide a tire two weeks ago, 17 miles from home. Rode out on a flat ‚Ä¶. We have goatheads and they‚Äôve saved me when everyone else went flat. Gravel Girl
